sect2.title: Outback Power Systems
sect2.para: Unlike the Xantrex products, the Outback products support a real protocol with real flow control.

sect3.title: Serial Port
sect3.para: The Outback serial port runs at 19200 baud, 8 data bits, no parity, and 1 stop bit. Outback appears to use real UARTs, thank you!

sect4.title: Flow Control
sect4.para: Flow control to an Outback product is done via the DTR and RTS pins on the serial cable. This is a non-standard way to control the flow of data, but it works. For data to flow, the DTR pin must be held HIGH (on), and the RTS pin must be held LOW (off). Toggling either DTR or RTS pins achieves the same effect, but I've been using the DTR pin myself. To get a clean connection, you'll also want to turn off any XON/XOFF types of flow control.

I have also noticed that there are no serial communications programs that run under Unix that can handle this style of flow control. Both Kermit and Minicom only support the standard ways of flow control, and don't let you selectively turn off or on the serial port pins. On Windows I've been told that the only program that does this correctly is called
Terminal I added a "console" mode to PowerGuru so I can use my own software rather than depend on 3rd party software that doesn't do the trick.

sect3.title: MX Message Frame
sect3.para: An MX status message frame is comprised of 49 ASCII numerical characters. A newline used to signify the start of a frame and carriage return is used to signify the end of the frame. These are the only two non ASCII in a message.

On my MX60 (bought roughly 2003), the address field is always wrong. On my unit it says '0', as if it were an FX inverter. Maybe this is because I don't have an FX inverter, I have a Xantrex (Trace) 4024. I plan to put an FX inverter in the Solar Lab, but right now I'm still dealing with saving up the cash for one...

entry.para: This is an New Line character denoting the start of the status page.
The MX address is an ASCII 'A' for unit 0, and an ASCII 'B' to 'K' for the other 9 units.
ASCII Zero characters are used to fill unused fields.
Range 00-99. This is the current the charger is putting into the batteries. 1 amp increments are used.
Range 00-99. The current coming from the photovoltaic panels. 1 amp increments are used.
Range 000-256. This is the voltage coming from the photovoltaic panels to the charge controller.
Range 000-999. This is the daily kilowatt hours used since daybreak.
ASCII Zero characters are used to fill unused fields.
Range 00-99. This is the current Auxilary Mode. The value is used to do a tabke lookuop for the mode.
Range 000-256. The Error Mode is currently unimplemented in the MX.
Range 00-99. The MX Charger Mode is used to do a table lookup for the mode.

Range 000-999. The Battery Voltage is a 3 digit floating point number with the last digit as the fraction. So 251 volts becomes 25.1 volts. Resolution is 0.1V for 12V, 0.2 for 24V, and 0.4 for 48V systems.
ASCII Zero characters are used to fill unused fields.
ASCII Zero characters are used to fill unused fields.
Range 000-999. The Message checksum is calculated be adding all the digits of the message together, one at a time.
The end of the message frame is a Carriage Return.

sect4.title: MX Message Data Tables
sect4.para: There are a few tables used to lookup values from the messages. Error codes are not implemented at this time, but the Auxilary and Charger Mode data fields both need to be looked up from a tables.

sect5.title: MX Auxilary Modes
sect5.para: The Auxilary mode is the current mode running on the MX.

sect5.title: MX Charger Modes
sect5.para: The Charger mode is the current operating mode of the charger.

sect3.title: FX Message Frame
sect3.para: An FX status message frame is comprised of 49 ASCII numerical characters. A newline used to signify the start of a frame and carriage return is used to signify the end of the frame. These are the only two non ASCII in a message.

entry.para: This is an New Line character denoting the start of the status page.
The FX address is an ASCII 'A' for unit 0, and an ASCII 'B' to 'K' for the other 9 units.
Range 00-99. This is the current the inverter is putting into the loads. 1 amp increments are used.
Range 00-99. This is the current the charger is putting into the batteries from the AC Input. 1 amp increments are used.
Range 00-99. This is the current the charger is putting into the batteries and pass thru loads from the AC Input. 1 amp increments are used.
Range 000-256. This is the voltage coming in the AC Input. If the Misc byte is set, multiply this by 2. 1 amp increments,
Range 000-999. This is the voltage of the inverter's AC output. If the Misc byte is set, multiply this by 2. 1 amp increments,
Range 00-99. This is the current the inverter is putting into the batteried from the AC Input.
Range 00-99. The value is used to do a table lookuop for the mode.
Range 000-256. This is a bit field represening an error, if there is one. Multiple errors can be returned at the same time in the bit field.
Range 00-99. The FX AC Mode is used to do a table lookup for the actual value.

Range 000-999. The Battery Voltage is a 3 digit floating point number with the last digit as the fraction. So 251 volts becomes 25.1 volts. Resolution is 0.1V for 12V, 0.2 for 24V, and 0.4 for 48V systems.
This is a bit field used to possible modify the the voltage readings, or to signify the AUX output is on.
Range 000-999. The Message checksum is calculated be adding all the digits of the message together, one at a time.
The end of the message frame is a Carriage Return.

sect4.title: FX Message Data Tables
sect4.para: There are a few tables used to lookup values from the messages. The Operational and AC Input Mode data fields both need to be looked up from a tables.

sect5.title: FX Operational Modes
sect5.para: The Operational mode is the current operating mode of the inverter.

sect5.title: FX Error Modes
sect5.para: This is the error code, if any, of the inverter. Multiple errors can be returned at the same time in the bitmask.

sect5.title: FX AC Input Modes
sect5.para: This is the current mode of the AC input.

sect5.title: FX Warning Modes
sect5.para: This is the warning code, if any, of the inverter. Multiple warnings can be returned at the same time in the bitmask.
